Dr. Alex Kalynychenko: A lecturer at the Department of Geography, Geomatics and Environment at the University of Toronto Mississauga.
University of Toronto Mississauga: A campus of the University of Toronto, hosting the Department of Geography, Geomatics and Environment.
GGR 321 H5S: A course taught by Dr. Alex Kalynychenko at the University of Toronto Mississauga, focused on Geographic Information Processing.
Spatial Analysis I & II: Topics covered in the lecture, focused on answering geospatial questions and solving location-oriented problems.
ESRI: A company that provides geographic information system software, web GIS and geodatabase management applications. Referenced as the source of certain materials and demos in the lecture.
Carl Steinitz: A scholar known for his work in geodesign
Longley et al. (2015): A source of information discussing various concepts related to GIS, including redistricting, centrality, and analysis of surfaces.
ArcGIS Pro extensions: Additional tools or features for the ArcGIS Pro software, used for various types of spatial and geospatial analysis.
Machine learning and AI: Techniques and algorithms used to automate the prediction, classification, and clustering of data, mentioned in the context of spatial analysis.
Deep learning: A subset of machine learning techniques that uses artificial neural networks to learn from data.
Big data analytics: The process of examining large and varied data sets to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, market trends, customer preferences and other useful information.
ArcGIS Pro: A geographic information system for working with maps and geographic information maintained by the Environmental Systems Research Institute (Esri)
Spark: An open-source, distributed computing system used for big data processing and analytics.
ESRI 2024: A source of information related to geoprocessing and Python scripting in the context of geographic information systems (GIS).
Modeling and scripting: A concept in GIS that involves creating and executing scripts, often in Python, to automate geoprocessing tasks.
Python: A high-level, general-purpose programming language often used in GIS for scripting and automation.
ModelBuilder: A visual programming language for building geoprocessing workflows in ArcGIS, a GIS software developed by ESRI.
Zandbergen (2024): A source of information discussing the purpose of area-based analyses in geography and GIS.
Area-Based Analyses: A method in geography and GIS where characteristics are ascribed to entire areas rather than individual points.
Polygon: A plane figure that is described by a finite number of straight line segments connected to form a closed polygonal chain or polygonal circuit.
Redistricting: The process of drawing electoral district boundaries in the United States, often associated with gerrymandering.
Gerrymandering: A practice intended to establish an unfair political advantage for a particular party or group by manipulating district boundaries.
23rd Congressional District: An old congressional district in California, mentioned in the context of redistricting.
24th District: A new, more compact congressional district in California, created after redistricting.
Centrality: A concept in geography and GIS that involves numerical measures of central tendency, such as mean, median, and mode.
Centers: Two-dimensional equivalents of the mean, used to summarize the locations of a set of points in GIS.
Centroid or mean center: The most convenient way of summarizing the locations of a set of points in GIS, found by taking the weighted average of the x and y coordinates.
U. S. Bureau of the Census: The government agency responsible for the United States Census. It provides data about the nation's people and economy.
Dispersion: A measure of how much the data values are spread out, often measured by standard deviation or variance in GIS.
Standard deviation: A measure that quantifies the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
Variance: A statistical measurement of the spread between numbers in a data set.
RMSE: Root Mean Square Error, a measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values observed.
Analysis of Surfaces: A concept in GIS that involves the study of surface characteristics, including slope, aspect, travel, watersheds, and channels.
DEM: Digital Elevation Model, a 3D representation of a terrain's surface created from terrain elevation data.
https://www.travelassociates.com/: Website URL, possibly related to the source material or the topic being discussed
Orange County DEM: Digital Elevation Model of Orange County, a 3D representation of a terrain's surface
River Channels: Paths where a river flows or could flow
Santa Ana River: A river in Southern California that flows from the San Bernardino mountains to the Pacific Ocean
Gorge: A narrow valley between hills or mountains, typically with steep rocky walls and a stream running through it
Pacific: The Pacific Ocean, where the Santa Ana River empties
Seal Beach: A coastal city in Orange County, California
Newport Beach: A coastal city in Orange County, California, where the Santa Ana River actually empties
Geodesign: A design and planning method which tightly couples the creation of design proposals with impact simulations informed by geographic contexts
Location-allocation problems: Problems that involve determining where to place facilities and how to allocate demand to them
p-median problem: A problem that seeks optimum locations for a certain number of central facilities to minimize the sum of the distances between each demand point and its nearest facility
Coverage problem: A problem that seeks to minimize the furthest distance traveled from a demand point to a facility
Hakimiâ€™s theorem: A theorem in network theory that states only junctions (nodes) in the network and places where there is demand need to be considered when solving location-allocation problems
Routing problems: Problems that involve determining the optimal paths or routes for vehicles or deliveries
Shortest-path problem: A problem that finds the shortest path through a network between a defined origin and destination
Traveling-salesman problem (TSP): A problem that seeks to determine the shortest possible route that visits each city once and returns to the origin city
Orienteering problem: A problem similar to TSP but the objective is to maximize the rewards associated with visiting a selection of the stops while minimizing the total distance traveled
Sears: An American chain of department stores
Hypothesis testing: A statistical method that uses sample data to evaluate a hypothesis about a population
Randomization tests: Statistical tests that simulate a large number of random arrangements of the data
Santa Barbara: A city in California, north of which the sample of points for vegetation cover class and elevation is taken
Spatial Analysis: A type of geographical analysis which seeks to explain patterns of human behavior and its spatial expression in terms of mathematics and geometry, that is, locational analysis
Quiz 4: An assessment that will be administered via Quercus next week, covering materials from Week 9&10 Spatial Analysis I&II and recommended readings.
Quercus: The platform through which Quiz 4 will be administered.
Week 9&10 Spatial Analysis I&II: The subject matter that Quiz 4 will cover, presumably part of the course curriculum.
Recommended readings: Additional materials suggested for study in preparation for Quiz 4.
Lab 3: A lab session that is scheduled to occur on Thursday, March 13, 2025.
Thursday, March 13, 2025: The date on which Lab 3 is scheduled to occur.
